Reviews.Title: “Bargain Hunters - yes/Perfectionists - no”
Reviews.Author: dmbt
Reviews.Content: I would actually rate this hotel as "fair' or "acceptable". If you're looking for a low cost stay in a convenient location in the city of Baltimore, and your willing to overlook the fact the hotel has probably seen better days, as I was, then you'll be fine here for a night or so. Pros: reasonable price good location convenient parking ($3) clean beds and bathrooms pleasant, helpful staff Cons: old property (some would say "run down") lots of stairs/ no elevator potential to be loud not for children The Biltmore is over a hundred years old and the floors and walls are no longer square. There is no elevator. The lobby is a flight up from the street and the rooms start above that. There are two flights of stairs for each floor, so the lowest room would be two flights up from the lobby, and the fourth floor, where I stayed with my teenage daughters, requires ascending (and descending) eight flights of stairs. Our room had two queen beds with a small sitting room and bathroom off of that. The beds and the bathroom were clean, which is the most important thing to me, while the rugs, furniture, curtains and such were somewhat shabby. There was a water stain on the bathroom ceiling, and there was also some peeling wallpaper and plaster in the bedroom which is one of the reasons I would not recommend this hotel for young children or toddlers. There was a cable outlet hanging from the wall by its wires down low as well, and the windows opened up with no kind of screens or safety devices to keeps little ones from falling out - so adults or older children only. Parking is located about a block away in a hospital garage and costs $3 with validation from the hotel. It is free on weekends if it is unattended. Although we worried about the possibility of late-night ambulances waking us up, that didn't happen. We could hear our neighbors talking in adjacent rooms, but everyone was quiet at night. The staff was friendly, and although they were willing to gives us directions multiple times, they didn't really include street names so bring your GPS. Some would say this hotel has "Old World Charm", others would call it "run down". We were fine for the one night we needed to stay in Baltimore while visiting colleges, and it met my budget. If this description doesn't sound fine to you though, it probably won't be.

Reviews.Title: “Quirky but Charming”
Reviews.Author: Susan1958
Reviews.Content: I was a bit nervous based on some of the other reviews, but I fell in love with this place. The location was perfect for my trips to the Walters Art Museum and the free "Charm City Circulator" bus makes it very convenient to anywhere in the city. I felt perfectly safe in the neighborhood and left my car 2 blocks away at the Maryland General Hospital ($9 total parking cost for a 3-day stay). The Mount Vernon neighborhood is filled with lovely old buildings and I felt quite safe as a woman walking alone. My room (211) was a delightful surprise. Yes, it was up 41 steps, but it had an enormous sitting room as well as a large bedroom. The furniture was a wonderfully eclectic mix of antiques from all periods and the bed was quite comfortable. Yes, it could use a face lift, but it was very clean and comfortable. The microwave, coffee maker and mini-refrigerator all worked perfectly. There were plenty of drawers and closet space to store a month's worth of stuff. There were also plenty of lights and electrical outlets. I liked the decor and the artwork. My favorite was the antique sewing machine in the corner. I loved the view of the church spire out the sitting room window. The only thing I would change would be to get rid of the silk flowers, which looked a bit tired and dusty. The woman at the front desk was helpful and friendly. The bathroom was in need of work. There had been water damage on the ceiling which was warped and discolored and the handle on the tub was loose. However, it was clean and how much time do you spend in the bathroom anyway? Overall, I would recommend this place highly to anyone who is willing to accept some minor imperfections in exchange for a comfortable and memorable experience.

Reviews.Title: “The Worse Experience Ever”
Reviews.Author: lmlee8901
Reviews.Content: I am from the area and that was the worse experience of my life. It looked like the Adams Family house, the ceiling was peeling, mold around the shower and an actual cat walking around. I thought it would be shabby chic but i honestly felt as though norman bates was going to stab me in the shower. Do not I repeat don not stay there even though the price is alluring I couldnt do it. I actually left the hotel and got a refund

Reviews.Title: “OLD OLD OLD BUT CHARMING”
Reviews.Author: MSRGREER
Reviews.Content: GREAT LOCATION...close to both free bus and lite rail.room had everything needed micro fridge and 1 burner. mt vernon area which is old and very historic.could use a MAJOR update but served the purpose. shower and sleep. not the ritz but not the ritz prices either.would stay again.

Reviews.Title: “A warm, shabby chic gem in Baltimore!”
Reviews.Author: Lisa N
Reviews.Content: Being a frequent traveler to Europe, this hotel made me homesick for the quaint, bed and breakfast-like hotels in London. Although, this place seriously needs an elevator, it was an amazing, historical journey back to the Victorian 1800's in the heart of Mt. Vernon, Baltimore. Yes, this place is homely, but there are so many things to see and touch and has a museum-like quality. The lobby is an wonderful place to have coffee/tea and relax. Mr. Patel, the owner, was a joy to work with and very responsive to our needs. The bedroom suites were like real parlors and bedroom combinations. I found myself wanting to see each room out of curiosity as they were all decorated differently. If you can get the Biltmore Suite, Room 101, ask for it! The location is perfect and in close proximity to food, coffee shops, theaters, natural food stores, ethnic food places, bars, and museums. Hop on the Charm City Connector (free) and tour the city. Parking at the hotel is only available on the street and it can be hard to find a space at night since residents have priority, but if you find a space, stay in it and walk around. (Read the meters!) Look, if you are looking for a modern, sleek hotel (and one with an elevator), then avoid this hotel. You will look immediately to the cracks in the walls and the lived-in furniture. But if you are looking for a place that has a bit of Baltimore's historical charm, has a friendly approachable staff, and has a warm, shabby-ish decor, themed rooms, then this place is a gem!

Reviews.Title: “Never again”
Reviews.Author: Ernst R
Reviews.Content: This House ist unbelievable dirty and run down. No Elevator. The bedsheets had not been changed for some time. Dust everywhere. Wallpaper hanging down.

Reviews.Title: “I would stay at this place again in a heartbeat!”
Reviews.Author: CLKR
Reviews.Content: After reading reviews I was a little iffy about this place, but aside from the stairs, I loved the building, the room, and the staff. Especially Becky working evenings. Don't let the bad reviews scare you away. Its not cookie-cutter, but it is charing and very unique. And it was clean! A huge requirement for me and my crazy OCD.

Reviews.Title: “Avoid”
Reviews.Author: Tatiana2011
Reviews.Content: My husband and I had a wedding to go to in Baltimore and we chose this hotel because of the location and outstanding price. When we arrived we were so impressed by the beautiful exterior. Upon entering we started to become skeptical. There were babies screaming upstairs and very odd people just hanging out in the lobby. I started to feel as if perhaps these people were living here. We went up to our room which was giant. It was time for my shower so I headed to the bathroom and was totally disgusted. I mean it was probably the grossest bathroom I have ever been in. I was very careful not to let my body touch any part of the shower. In general I was very creeped out and had nightmares all night b/c I was afraid we would get robbed. It's not a fact but I am almost positive that at least 2 families were living in the rooms next to us. The walls are paper thin and we heard everything. I would not call myself a neat freak and can handle a certain degree of uncleanliness but this was beyond what I would deem appropriate hotel accommodations. I have been in hostels that were far better than this!

Reviews.Title: “I hope they never renovate!”
Reviews.Author: kendelld
Reviews.Content: the place is a once grand Victorian style hotel. Yes it needs updating, but I hope they never do any major renovations because this place is an amazing deal! For $54 a night, friday and saturday, we got a huge bedroom with a very comfy bed, an even bigger living room/dining room/ kitchenette room and a small, very dated bathroom. Yes, there was mildew in the caulk, but everything else was clean. And I work for the health depth and am very paranoid about bedbugs right now but found no signs of them. Staff was very helpful. I thought the neighborhood was beautiful - a huge gorgeous church across the street and plenty of beautiful architecture all around. We're walkers so we walked down Charles street and explored the restaurants on our way down to the inner harbor. It was about a 20 minuete walk. I never felt unsafe, even at 1 am. We were just starting a 9 day motorcycle trip. We parked our bikes for free in the bank parking lot and they were not touched-saddlebags are only secured with zippers and there were no issues.

Reviews.Title: “I didn't like it!”
Reviews.Author: Sem C
Reviews.Content: It is a very creepy place. It feels like a Tim Burton movie. I stayed there for 2 weeks. If I didn't pay during the check-in, I would definitely change my hotel. I chose this one because the hotels in Inner Harbor were a bit expensive. I felt really uncomfortable. I have been living alone almost for 4 years, and I often travel alone, but I never felt scared like this. I also didn't like the neighborhood. It is not safe for walking. The room was dusty. Wireless signal was very weak in my room. Some of the towels were not clean enough.

Reviews.Title: “BED BUGS - BEWARE.”
Reviews.Author: ehbg
Reviews.Content: I stayed at this hotel last weekend with my husband while we were visiting family. I should have read the reviews first, as I am not the first person to complain about bed bugs. The hotel was old and run down but I didn't mind. However, Room 212 has bed bugs. The morning after our second and last night there I woke up itching all over. I have never had to deal with bed bugs before and once we got home, I did some research online and also found a bed bug in my luggage. I called the hotel to let them know that they are putting their guests at risk of not only being bitten, but of bringing these pests back to their own homes. The hotel manager could have cared less and dismissed my warnings. I am appalled by this and am posting some photos of my bites (Trust me, I have plenty more photos)-- which continue to itch like crazy a week later. DO NOT STAY HERE. Pay the extra money to go to a place that won't put their guests at such risk.

Reviews.Title: “A hidden jewel in the city.”
Reviews.Author: Jenny_oJ
Reviews.Content: I booked this room online because it was the cheapest place in town and there was a convention in town that week. I was a little weary because I had read some reviews about it being in a bad part of town. I was very pleasantly surprised when I arrived at the actual hotel. It was an old beautiful building that I later found out was over a hundred years old and used to be a boarding house an a dormitory among other things. The staff was very helpful and kind. We booked a smoking room and were given a non-smoking, but were given a new room as soon as the clerk was informed of the mistake. Each room was unique and included a small kitchenette with a fridge and stove top. The rooms were old fashioned looking and had old fixtures in the bath but all was very clean. The section of town it was in was not as bad as I anticipated and we were directed to park in a parking garage about a half a block over. The clerk was extremely friendly and talked to us an answered questions for about an hour. He directed us two blocks over, which is really the heart of the city. I know that people usually want to do touristy things in the harbor, but the Biltmore is for those who like to explore the real Baltimore. There were lots of little local stores, art galleries and cool shops. There are no elevators in the Biltmore but that was not a discouragement for me at all. The building is unbelievable lovely. The rooms are nice and homey. It is a lot more like a bed and breakfast than a hotel. I really am hard pressed to believe the bad reviews on here. I absolutely adored the place. The common room had sofas and a bookcase and even a cat! We were traveling on a small budget and the night clerk allowed us to used the microwave in the downstairs kitchen to prepare our meals. I am planning a trip to Baltimore specifically to stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Don't Believe Every BAD review you read!!!!”
Reviews.Author: DontayJenn
Reviews.Content: I read all of the reviews that were on here before I booked a stay. At first alittle discourage but I went with my gut feeling and booked a stay anyway. And glad I did the attendance were awesome. The room was beautiful Living room, kitchen, dining area, Im from baltimore and i stayed at some horrible places that was suppose to be nice but the Biltmore Stood past its expectations to me and my wife. when we visit baltimore again I know where we staying.. BILTIMORE BABY.....

Reviews.Title: “Funky Victorian - the old girl is still great”
Reviews.Author: AnnaMargaret
Reviews.Content: I almost hesitate to spill this secret...I needed to go to Johns Hopkins and my budget dictated this or the "seen 'em all" Microtel. Glad I ventured off the beaten path! Locted in the Mt. Vernon cultural district, this is the real deal, a once grand, now good, all suites hotel, with a salon so large you could have a party or sleep a girl scout troop in there. Biltmore bows deeply to its Victorian past in decor. Woodwork is in 1870s Stick-Eastlake style, both in the ornate banister we caressed as we climbed the twisting staircase and in the two fireplaces in our suite. Sure, the furniture was a bit scuffed, but for $80 a night, microfridge, coffeemaker, ample towels, completely comfortable. My only regret was I couldn't live here a week. Next time I'll bring my own hairdryer and drive past the hotel to the hospital parking garage in the next block for their co-op parking at $3 with validation.

Reviews.Title: “NEVER...EVER, WILL WE STAY AT THIS HOTEL AGAIN.. Thanks Priceline...”
Reviews.Author: erjr52
Reviews.Content: To make a long story short, we took the bus up to Bmore, checked in and without laying down- began a full day of taking care of family business. All things considered we were successful on that point. We met with frineds at the Inner Harbor and called it a night with a night cap. Showered down in a bathroom with holes in the drywall, mildew stains embedded in the seamwork and bugs on the floormat. We really did not mind that three of the lamps inside the room were missing light bulbs, nor the fact that a chair in the room had a storage covering on it. We were only interested in having a place to lay our heads. After showering, which took a bit of time because the water pressure was low and coming out of the main spout, we bedded down but woke up later on with sever itching. I did not see the bugs on the spread or the covers, but did get a glance at a couple on the pillow casings. They had bitten us so bad that the whelts were half dollar sized for almost three days. The young man on duty contacted to GM/Owner who invited us to leave citing that- if we did so we would not be charged for our use of the room. We explained that we came on the bus and had nowhere to go, the young man then went further to try and put us into another room one flight above us, but with no elevator and our very tired souls; who had the energy. We were trapped, we slept in the chairs until daybreak with towels covering us because we did not trust the sheets or coverings. Needless to say, the next morning when the GM/Owner came in- he was quick to state that they have never had complaints of "BED BUGS", and also recinded the offer of "No Charge" and would only knock off $25.00 from the one night stay. We had to remind this guy and even showed him the whelts left on our backs. But he would only take half off the total price. We had to settle this quick and get back home before our scheduled departure. Otherwise we would have missed our bus because of the construction to the Lightrail. I wish someone could have pointed me in the right direction before I made this reservation, if the Owner of the Biltmore is reading this, the swelling on my back is beginning to subside and this is the third day (A**HOLE). If I had a torch I would rather burn this place down versus staying there for even a fraction of second; Buyer Beware!!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Fair enough”
Reviews.Author: rataRva
Reviews.Content: Before I booked the room at this place, I saw all these reviews here, and was making me double guess whether I should stay here or not; I took the chance. You pay for what you get, I don’t really have any complaints other than there being no elevator. The bathrooms were clean, the rooms were descent, good customer service. The Hotel is in a really good spot, close to the Inner Harbor (about a mile away), and close to downtown. I had a good experience, will totally stay again if visiting Baltimore some time again in the future.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointing: far from Inner Harbor, bit shabby, neighborhood iffy.”
Reviews.Author: PhiladelphiaRobbi
Reviews.Content: Location left much to be desired: we were told it was pretty close to Inner Harbor, which it wasn't; there is a trolley, but after dark, even walking a block or two from trolley stop to hotel was a bit scary in the deserted neighborhood. The long walk during daylight wasn't scary but also wasn't pleasant. Was less expensive than Inner Harbor hotels, but not by that much, and not worth the difference. Room itself wasn't too bad (good exercise getting to 4th floor walk-up, but no fun with the luggage), nice view of church across street, but was rather shabby.

Reviews.Title: “Very Surprised after the initial shock”
Reviews.Author: Xtremetude
Reviews.Content: I booked this room off of the internet, the pics on the site were nice, but when we got to the hotel and I went in I could see the the building truly was built in the late 1800s. The building was situated about 12 blocks or so out of the "Inner Harbor" part of town. The neighborhood is not somewhere that I would choose to live but it wasn't all that bad. You had to ring a bell to get into the building so no one can just walk in, I liked that. The hotel was very interesting to say the least, the furniture was old but it "fit" into the make up of the hotel. I had booked a room with a king size bed. We went to the room and it was really nice, had a king sized bed as promised, and also a private sitting room, the AC was "FREEZING" WE HAD TO SHUT IT OFF and we both love the AC, the TV worked fine with no complaints. The bed was very very comfortable and clean. Yes the furniture is old but like I said it added to the quaintness of the hotel. The staff was very nice to say the least. Room was well worth the money we spent on it. All and all I would stay here again, parking was not a problem either, just 1/2 block up and in a secure hospital parking garage at a discount. And oh yeah I loved Simon the cat :)

Reviews.Title: “They cancelled my room!!”
Reviews.Author: erin10ann
Reviews.Content: I contacted the hotel and reserved a room over the phone 1 month prior to our arrival date. I called to confirm the reservation 2 days before arriving....I was told I was all set and they would see me 2 days later. I arrive twenty minutes after check in time and was told my room was cancelled. They had NO record of it being cancelled. No date, time or staff member that cancelled it. When asked what they would do to assist me in finding a new place to stay since ALL OF BALTIMORE was booked I was told there was nothing they could do. It took me two and a half hours and a twenty minute drive outside of the city to find a place to stay. The staff was rude, non apologetic and quite frankly ignorant. I would not recommend even boarding your dog here.

Reviews.Title: “Really enjoyed our stay”
Reviews.Author: Pete222
Reviews.Content: This hotel is ideally situated for seeing Baltimore. It is a 10 minute walk from Baltimore's Penn Station so you can come in on AmTrak or Marc trains. It is 2 minutes to the urban light rail stop. The neighborhood is extremely walkable and I walked all over the city during our stay. The Mount Vernon neighborhood is extremely well populated with good restaurants and such. The architecture is pure eye candy. The hotel staff was very friendly and provided good information. Our room was super large with a separate sitting room. This was perfect because my wife needed quiet to study up for a presentation. We had good wireless network access in our room. The bed was comfortable. The shower put out good hot water. This building is more than 100 years old so things are not new. Floors are not perfectly level and carpets not new but everything was clean.

Reviews.Title: “Long on quirks, short on service”
Reviews.Author: LeosTravels
Reviews.Content: Quaint and quirky are the polite terms to describe this place. It certainly feels like your imaginary great-grandma's big-city rooming house (or did she run a halfway house?), with all that entails. It's not horrible and does indeed have some charm, but it's hard not to feel a little cheated by the poor upkeep and service. Yes, it's one of the cheaper properties near downtown, but it's not so cheap that you don't notice the broken toilet seat and towel rack, the missing alarm clock, or the fact that housekeeping manages to skip your room two days in a row. The list goes on. As others have pointed out, sound carries easily through the walls and on top of that, while I was there at least, more than a couple guests had a penchant for loud conversations in the halls and banging on each others' doors at night. I was optimistic at the start and was fine to accept certain quirks instead of staying in a cookie-cutter room somewhere else as others have said. But the management's sheer apathy wore me down as I discovered each new problem. If it were only a finance problem for them, all they'd have to do is raise rates $5 a night for one week in order to afford some of the minor annoyances they let persist. So I figure they don't care. And I have to add my vote to those of people who said before me: "Never again."

Reviews.Title: “The worst place I have been so far”
Reviews.Author: Mac_Powers
Reviews.Content: This place has seen its best times decades ago. It is dirty (I had the obligatory blood stains on my towels) and smelly (even with opening both windows fully, I could recognize the smell in the morning). I left the place after one night (and would have done it earlier, if I hadn´t arrived in the middle of the night). The only positive thing about the hotel is the area around.

Reviews.Title: “In the morning, I felt a little itchy”
Reviews.Author: NewYorkTraveler_NYC
Reviews.Content: Biltmore Suites is ok for a quick, overnight stay - especially if you are looking for an inexpensive room in Baltimore. The staff is very accommodating & pleasant, but this charming inn is in dire need of renovation. Overall, the interior decor (both in the common areas and rooms) is old - a "grandma" look and feel with Salvation Army quality furniture. I traveled with family, and on a positive note, my room offered a large layout with king bed, sitting area, kitchenette, and bathroom. Unfortunately, the spacious room was spoiled by a variety of creepy, mis-matched furniture, blood red window treatments, a kitchenette with aluminum foil covered burners, bathroom walls with small holes stuffed with tissue paper, a tub with a funky foot sticker, a pipe sticking out of the tub wall, a wood platform keeping the toilet from going under, and multiple stains and holes on sheets. My cousin offered every member of my family a thoughful turndown service with chocolates - only to discover flat, disappointing pillows. Another cousin attempted to open her window curtains, only to have them fall on top of her. In the morning, I used the rooms coffee maker, sat with a weak cup of coffee and non dairy creamer at one of the room's side tables, and pondered the day ahead. Everyone reported they had a good nights sleep, but I have to admit, I felt a little itchy.

Reviews.Title: “Sweetest little Hotel! Very unique experience!”
Reviews.Author: Zmel110
Reviews.Content: We stayed here as a group attending a friend's wedding. I fell in love with this cute little hotel. It is a truly unique experience. It helped that everyone at the hotel was there for the wedding, but I certainly fell in loooove with this facility. Very cute old fashioned hotel. We had a nice little balcony that we could use. The common area was fantastic. The customer service was awesome too. Over all a great experience.

Reviews.Title: “Character abound. Hotel is not for everyone. American charm in the area.”
Reviews.Author: pastadutchie
Reviews.Content: This hotel is in the beautiful district of Mount Vernon in Baltimore inside a Victorian style building. The area is considered a National Landmark Historic District and it shows. A lot of construction is happening in the area as many older buildings are being renovated, as well as the streets. This hotel however, is a little late in receiving it's make over. Our room included: - 1 king bed, night tables - TV - breakfast table and chairs - full bathroom with bathtub - second room with mini-kitchen, couch, access to bathroom - free parking LOCATION Close to Inner Harbor, Lexington Market, Camden Yards, John Hopkins, the Washington monument, University of Baltimore, and Pennsylvania (Penn) Station with easy and cheap access ($14 return) to DC. The area itself is historical and beautiful with lots of character. If you appreciate history and architecture, you will definitely like the area. Pretty good selection of restaurants within the area that were surprisingly good. The hotel is a short trip off the I-83 on West Madison Street near the Maryland General Hospital. Some people in other reviews were bothered by the homelessness in the area. We saw a fair bit, but were never harassed (they asked for money and give what you can), and actually found one to be helpful with directions to attractions. AMENITIES The area is the real amenity. The hotel offers a free continental breakfast and wireless internet at $10. Cable TV is in the room, is that even an amenity anymore? PARKING No parking directly with the hotel. They recommend you go to the Maryland General Hospital, where you can park for a hotel-negotiated $3.00 rate. We stayed 3 nights, and the parking lot attendant was nice and only charged us $7.00 in total. The lot seems secure and patrolled. CLEANLINESS The lobby, rooms, and hallways were kept relatively clean. COMFORT The furniture and decor of the entire hotel is quite dated, but it has character. Everything is in need of an upgrade. Much of the hotel hasn't had much work for many years. Peeling wallpaper, peeling paint on the walls, stained tiles and holes in the walls. The floor boards were broken under the carpet in our room, and many areas in the hotel are lopsided. That said, everything worked, it was clean, and...we'll leave it at that. The pictures will tell the rest. SERVICE Excellent. Staff was friendly and helpful, the continental breakfast was ready every morning, and the wireless internet worked well. The hotel wasn't busy and they upgraded us to a larger room. OVERALL It was of good value given the competition in the area. About $120 per night. The place is in pretty rough condition, but it's much more affordable than other hotels in the area. I really hope they restore the building as it is beautiful, and modernize the rooms. That said, I think I might stay at the Biltmore again when in the Baltimore/Washington DC area due to the value. Try the Afghani restaurant around the corner if you like lamb dishes. It was fantastic.

Reviews.Title: “A pleasant surprise”
Reviews.Author: Pavelesco
Reviews.Content: My partner and I went to Baltimore for a weekend before a business travel to DC. He was quite familiar to the neighborhood, so it was not a surprise the convenient location of this hotel, 2 or 3 streets from Charles St. and a less than 10usd taxi fare from Penn Station. It is easy to find good places to eat and have a beer walking distance from the hotel (Sacha's Bar is the best and it's on Charles St very close to Peabody conservatory, and there are also good options for bars like Brewer's Art and Grand Central -the latter gay- both in the same street) The hotel is an old mansion, with a lobby/parlor, where there is a small counter. Our first impression of the service was a little bit cold, but then most of the staff have a good service attitude. The room we got was a big bed room, with a small kitchenette, table for two and a sofa. The room was clean and has nice natural light. The bathroom was a little bit small, but still functional. In general the building is o.k. but need some re-carpeting. It has an old elevator (no more than 2 occupants) but still works. We were just a little bit worried about the hotel cause the other reviews we read, but for the 120usd per night we payed, we received a fairly good service, a nice comfortable bed and a great location.

Reviews.Title: “Not Business Traveler friendly”
Reviews.Author: saleschich
Reviews.Content: Just want business travelers to know this hotel is not business friendly. I was on a 3 week extended trip and had the possibility of having to stay the night in Baltimore. I booked through my employer travel agency. 8 minutes later we decided to meet in Colorado. I called the hotel directly to cancel. The reservation had not shown up yet but they assured me they would cancel. I called back 10 minutes later to ensure they did once the reservation showed. Long story short, they didn't cancel, charged me anyway, and then refused to credit my corporate card, citing a 48 hour cancellation policy. I work for a very large corporation and have never had this happen before. I'll stick with Marriott/Hilton, etc

Reviews.Title: “Very cute and charming!”
Reviews.Author: minger71
Reviews.Content: My work booked me at the Biltmore Suites Hotel. I was a bit wary after reading the reviews on Tripadvisor, but once I walked into my room, my first thought was "it's so cute!" and when I saw the bathroom (clean), my fears were put aside. As other reviewers have put it, if you like the standard sterile hotel room, with everything up-to-date, then this is not the place for you. However, if you like history and charm (and possibly are willing to put up with a few idiosyncracies), then this is a very cute hotel. For me, it was extremely convenient, since it was within walking distance of a conference held at the University of Baltimore (others at other hotels like the Radisson had to walk or drive, and one person got her car towed!). I found the staff very friendly, and were willing to help in getting the right forms so that my company would be charged. The biggest delight of my room was the 4-poster bed. The mattress was a little soft, so if you have back problems, you might want to sleep elsewhere. The room had a small stove, sink and refrigerator (perfect for putting restaurant leftovers to munch on later), and a table with 2 place settings. It also had a non-working fireplace that was a nice touch. The room had cable TV, although the remote control didn't really work. The bathroom (very important to me) was clean, and I had no problem with hot water or water pressure (I was in room 214 on the 3rd floor). I did have a colleague in another room who said her bathroom ceiling leaked a little. I had hangers in a walk-in closet to hang up my work clothes, and the room had a full-length mirror. I didn't feel like the air freshener was too strong. I stayed during the summer, and when I first walked in, the room was very hot. But once I turned the AC on, the room was very comfortable. I didn't get to eat breakfast, so I can't comment on that, but there is a water cooler in the lobby, if you don't like to drink tap water. The lobby was very nice. The hotel is old and a bit worn--e.g. it could use a new paint job in certain areas, but I didn't feel that it was dirty. The entrance is up some steps, and the door is very heavy. If you are physically disabled or have leg problems, then you might have some trouble with the entrance. Also, I didn't ride the elevator, but it looked very very small. The area around the hotel looked very interesting. I live in a city so to me, the area didn't feel bad at all. In fact, I thought the neighborhood was quite charming and there are a bunch of independent (non-chain) restaurants that I would have liked to have tried. The inner harber area is about a 30 minute walk, and the hotel is very close to the Walthers Art Musuem (which I didn't get to go to). It's about a 5-10 minute cab ride (or 15-20 minute walk) to the Amtrak train station. The room was $99/night + tax. In all, I had a good stay and it worked very well for my purpose. If you prefer new shiny hotels, then this is not the place for you, but if you like hotels with character, then you might like the Biltmore.

Reviews.Title: “Good potential, not quite there yet”
Reviews.Author: Wheezy_Dave
Reviews.Content: I really wanted to like the Biltmore Suites, but it didn't live up to its potential for a number of reasons. It seemed like a good alternative to the high-priced, crowded convention hotels around the Inner Harbor, but not quite good enough. My room had a sitting room (with a daybed and TV) and a separate bedroom along with the bathroom. The room was clean, but the room and the hallways had a air-freshener scent that remained in my bags and clothes after I returned home. The furniture in the room was rather dated. The TV set, for instance, had a loud buzz until the set 'warmed up' after about 15 minutes. The bedroom had an armoire for storing clothes, but no hangers. I asked for some hangers at the front desk, but they didn't have any either, so I left my dress shirts piled on the daybed for my three-night visit. Not the end of the world, but still an annoyance. A much larger problem was the lack of hot water on two of my three mornings there. Apparently there was a problem with the pilot light in the boiler that served my room and another one, and I happened to be the first one up. Not having hangers is one thing, not having hot water is another. (The hot water worked at night, so I had to adjust my showering schedule). There's not a lot of dining in the neighborhood, and the hotel doesn't offer room service, so don't return to the room hungry. On the plus side, the location is in a nice quiet neighborhood. The Mount Vernon cultural attractions are a short walk way, and It's about a half-hour walk to the convention center, which may or may not be a problem for some travelers. (Charles Street seemed like a safer choice than Howard for walking downtown). It's less than a five-minute walk to the light rail, which was very convenient to the convention center and Orioles Park. The staff was nice, and the rates were a lot lower than the Inner Harbor hotels, but then again, they probably had hot water in the morning.

Reviews.Title: “Take a careful look before staying”
Reviews.Author: Boztel
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Biltmore 07-08 Apr 06 for a Red Sox (read all hotels crowded) weekend. We were prepared for an older smaller hotel but even at a reduced rate would not choose to stay there again. If you choose to stay here I would recommend getting a clear description of the room assigned with a specific location and size discussion. A loud elevator plus loud guests made for a sleepless night. Call ahead and negotiate the lowest possible rate in a true suite room. Our room was quite small with a bathroom in disrepair. Found hot water to be at a premium and the continental breakfast (no juice) quite poor.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel, Great Deal”
Reviews.Author: sonichaggis
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Biltmore and highly enjoyed our stay. The staff was helpful and friendly and the hotel was funky and charming and well-located. We had a room in the back - you had to go through a small courtyard and the room had two fireplaces, a sitting area and was quite comfortable. The size and character of the room were amazing for the price. We found it quite reasonable. Many hotels in Baltimore were full that weekend and we thought we would end up paying big money to find a place, but were totally happy and pleasantly surprised to find this convenient, cool place at a decent price. We were in town to go to Camden Yards and the 15 minute walk to the Inner Harbor area was pleasant and easy. This is an older building with an emphasis on character so if you are expecting/wanting a large (sterile) hotel chain, this might not be the place for you. However, we'd recommend it and would stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Holy Cow!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Not what we expected. The ratings far exceed the accommodations. Don't let the internet pictures fool you. The room was neat & clean, but the walls are very thin. You can hear everyone's conversations until the wee hours of the night. There were water marks in the shower ceiling & the carpet must have been the original one. The staff was courteous & very helpful. They say 10 blocks from Inner Harbor, felt more like 100. We will not be staying at this Biltmore again anytime soon.

Reviews.Title: “"For Old Hotel Junkies only"”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I recently stayed at the Biltmore Suites Hotel (205 W. Madison Baltimore Md.) and I loved it. I am an old hotel junkie, though, and this hotel is not for guest who like chain hotels or cookie cutter rooms. When I was looking for a hotel with character in Baltimore, I read the reviews on this hotel, and they were very sharply split in opinion. I am in the pro-Biltmore group! I found the outside facade inviting and the salon more than adequate. The staff was extremely helpful, the location very good, and the elevator a trip back to the Past. The suite I booked was clean and spacious and fairly quiet for a hotel on a major downtown thoroughfare. The hotel also has wireless internet, which is something I needed. While I liked the Biltmore and plan to stay again, I must say that the rooms need someone to repair such trifling inconveniences as bureaus and armoires without pull handles -- hard to open drawers without any handles at all. Old hotels require more routine mantenance than it appears the Biltmore is receiving. The breakfast is marginal at best, and the hotel management is unable to cash traveler's checks. This, however, is only a slight inconvenience as there is a bank two doors down. The hotel is within walking distance of the Inner Harbor and Penn Station, as well as a block from the Light Rail and cabs are plentiful. I would stay there again for the staff and atmosphere.

Reviews.Title: “Good Value with Charm”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed in our own room while two (2) other husband and wife couples stayed in their own rooms for one night. This old hotel was built in the 1800's and offers spacious rooms with high ceilings to the public for 1/3 the cost of staying in hotels within the Inner Harbor. This hotel is not for everyone. Be in good shape to carry your own bags up the approximately 15 steps from the street level to reach the lobby to check-in for the night. There are no porters, nor any baggage carts provided for a hotel that was designed before the term "handicapped accessible" was coined. The elevator that takes you to your room is every bit as big as a large telephone booth (like Superman used to get dressed inside of) and you still have to climb a few stairs from the elevator landing up to the floor where your room is situated. Our room's A/C worked perfectly and the bed was quite comfortable. Although we were told a King-size bed awaited us it was more like a "double bed" (although a friend advised us it was a Queen size one). A table with place settings for two was provided and a sink, refrigerator, and stove were also part of the package. Yes, they had a retro-fifties air to them, but it was all academic since we simply enjoyed the complementary continental breakfast the next day anyway. Our room and bathroom were quite satisfactory. Our friends' rooms had some problems: Venetian blinds in the bathroom that would not shut/tilt properly for privacy and a shower dial that came-off in your hands. Wallpaper was falling-off in one of the rooms and the shower tiles close to the bathtub fixtures had started to cave-in. Parking was 1.5 blocks from the hotel which might be a challenge for others during inclement weather (not an issue for us that evening). Our smoke-free room was, indeed, free of any smokey smells. The front desk staff were quite polite and professional in their demeanor. We would stay there again but it's NOT for everyone.

Reviews.Title: “A great & friendly place to stay, I'll be a repeat customer”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I was concerned to stay at the Biltmore after reading some of these reviews (mainly the ones dealing with cleanliness), but it was too late to back out so I went for it. What I found was a great place that I will with out a doubt stay at again when in Baltimore. I felt like I got a bit of the charm of the city by staying at an old historic hotel. I would choose it again in a second over a chain hotel that gives you no taste of the actual city you are there to visit. My room was clean and spacious and the staff was beyond friendly. If you need a mint on your pillow and want only stark cookie cutter hotels, this might not be for you. The walls of this building show you the age of this magnificant building, but also tell a tale chain hotels could never speak. I will add that the decorations may have been a bit gaudy but not offensive and I wasn't there to get decorating tips anyway. Get this, my room (for only 75 bucks) had a queen sized bed, small fridge, a stove, private bath, table set for 2, cable TV and a closet. Enjoy.

Reviews.Title: “This place is a dump.”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Terrible! The halls and room appeared not have been vacuumed in 6 months. Walls and floors in extreme disrepair. Cheap plastic flowers were considered "decorations" UGH!

Reviews.Title: “An Oasis in Downtown Baltimore”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Enter the Biltmore Suites and you go back in time. Captured is the charm of its character. At 123 years old, it shows its wear like a beloved piece of clothing--maybe a button is gone or a stitch is loose, but you'd never think of replacing it with anything new. Ask to stay in a suite in the adjoining building, with a balcony! There's a small courtyard between the two buildings. You'll not regret staying in this oasis in Baltimore's downtown area!!

Reviews.Title: “Make sure to avoid”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The most memorable thing about this hotel was pulling the bedcovers back to reveal extremely thin and very badly stained pillow cases. The staff brought replacements that weren't much better. We stayed one night only because every other hotel in Baltimore was booked. Couldn't wait to get out the next morning.

Reviews.Title: “historic charm, good place to stay, but some cautions”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I had a reasonably comfortable stay at this hotel and would stay there again. The desk staff are extremely nice, gracious and hospitable -- and their English is fine. It's a beautiful old hotel, decaying grandeur, "decaying" being the operative word - there are some flaking plaster issues and obvious ceiling leaks that were patched. If you're not bothered by that kind of thing, you'll be fine. It's right in the middle of the historic district. Walk a few blocks to the right, you're in a lovely historic section with shops, cafes, restaurants, a monument. Walk to the left - along the light rail tracks -- and you're in the "seedy" part. It's fine in the day but scary at night, at dark. As a single woman traveler, I felt fine on Charles Street (historic section) but not at all safe on Harbor Street (the light rail stop) - I ran all the way back to the hotel, and I'm comfortable in most cities. Convention Center / Inner Harbor are easily accessible. 15 minute walk, or 7 minutes on the light rail, easy to use, good value. The room was cold, the heat didn't work well, not all the light bulbs worked, and there was no hair dryer. But the place was clean, and surprisingly spacious. I probably wouldn't stay there if I planned to "hang out" at a hotel a lot. It was a good, reasonably priced place to crash, very convenient to places I needed to be.

Reviews.Title: “Charming Old Hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This charming old hotel might be a little dingy, but the charm factor makes it worthwhile. The staff were very nice and the desk staff spoke english just fine. We had booked 2 queen rooms for $69 a night and when they didn't have them upon check in, we got stepped up to 1 king and one queen suite for no extra charge! The area around the hotel is so-so but not terrible. I parked my car in front with no problems. I loved the rickety elevator! I would certainly stay here again as would the friends who traveled with me.

Reviews.Title: “Love the Biltmore Suites Hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This is a very different kind of hotel. It is not your run-of-the-mill, sterile, franchise hotel. I was there with my kids and the kids loved the antique elevator. The elevator is a European-style with two gates. The rooms were large and the front desk manager was kind enough to upgrade our regular room with two double beds to an enormous suite with a sleeper sofa. The staff was very friendly and even called me after I checked in to ask if everything is okay in the room. I have not been asked this at any other hotel in Baltimore and I come to Baltimore quite often when the Yankees play at Camden Yards. I will stay at this hotel from now on. Also, the rates were very reasonable compared to the other hotels in Downtown Baltimore.

Reviews.Title: “Adorable and funky--but not for everyone”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This is the place to stay in Baltimore if you are on a budget, or if you enjoy seeking out the funky and offbeat. Yes, the floors slant, the elevator does not inspire confidence, and the carpets are well-worn. But the hotel has atmosphere to spare, in the form of a beautiful Victorian lobby, original architectural details, (non-working) fireplaces in rooms, and 12-foot ceilings. The staff could not have been more friendly and helpful, and the attention I received was far more personal and individual than is typically found in chain hotels. My room and linens were very clean and the room included a coffeemaker, cooktop, and refrigerator. The location is central to tourist attractions and hospitals, and the immediate neighborhood is quite safe; you do need to be careful of what directions you venture out into, and if you're not familiar with the area you should get some guidance on this in advance. However, I walked 3 blocks out to dinner and back after dark as a single woman and felt entirely safe. There are numerous ethnic retaurants and coffeehouses nearby. Finally, the price can't be beat: I paid $49 a night. (Check a travel discount website or call the hotel and ask for specials--there is almost always a deal well below rack rates). This hotel is not for everyone--it reminded me of old, small European hotels where there is a real sense of history. It's not the place for travelers who like things bright and brand-new, and not a good choice for physically disabled travelers due to a series of unavoidable steps at the entrance, and the fact that you may wish to use the stairs to your room rather than use the creaky old elevator. For me, though, this is the only place I'll stay in Baltimore in the future.

HotelInfo.Name: Biltmore Suites Hotel
HotelInfo.Address: 205 W. Madison St., Baltimore, MD 21201
